module.title: IDE Setup
module.description: Set up your development environment with VS Code for maximum productivity

lessons.title: Choosing Your Code Editor
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- VS Code is the industry standard for web development
- Your code editor is your primary tool as a developer
- Extensions and customization dramatically boost productivity
- Good setup saves hours of frustration

---

## Why Your Editor Matters

As a developer, you'll spend most of your day in your code editor. Choosing the right one and configuring it properly is one of the highest-impact decisions you can make for your productivity.

## Popular Code Editors

### VS Code (Recommended)
- Free and open-source
- Massive extension ecosystem
- Built-in Git integration
- IntelliSense (smart code completion)
- Used by 70%+ of web developers

### Alternatives
- **Cursor**: AI-powered editor built on VS Code
- **Zed**: Rust-based, extremely fast
- **WebStorm**: JetBrains IDE, paid but powerful
- **Neovim/Vim**: For keyboard-only warriors

## Installing VS Code

1. Download from [code.visualstudio.com](https://code.visualstudio.com)
2. Follow the installer for your OS
3. Launch VS Code
4. Install the recommended extensions (next lesson)

## First Launch Setup

When you first open VS Code:
- Choose your color theme (Dark+ is popular)
- Enable settings sync (saves config across devices)
- Familiarize yourself with the sidebar and panels

## Common Mistakes

- **Switching editors constantly**: Pick one and master it
- **Ignoring extensions**: They provide 50%+ of the value
- **Not learning shortcuts**: Mouse-driven development is slow
- **Skipping settings sync**: Lose your config when you switch computers

## Try It Yourself

1. Install VS Code if you haven't already
2. Open a folder with some code (or create one)
3. Try the command palette (Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + P)
4. Explore the sidebar icons

lessons.title: Essential VS Code Extensions
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- ESLint catches code errors automatically
- Prettier formats your code consistently
- GitLens supercharges Git integration
- Language extensions add syntax support

---

## Must-Have Extensions

### Code Quality
- **ESLint**: Real-time error detection for JavaScript/TypeScript
- **Prettier**: Automatic code formatting (saves endless debates)
- **Error Lens**: Shows errors inline, no hover needed

### Git Integration
- **GitLens**: See who changed what, when, and why
- **Git Graph**: Visualize your commit history

### Productivity
- **Auto Rename Tag**: Changes matching HTML/JSX tags together
- **Bracket Pair Colorizer 2**: Color-coded brackets for readability
- **Path Intellisense**: Autocomplete file paths
- **npm Intellisense**: Autocomplete npm modules in imports

### Language Support
- **Tailwind CSS IntelliSense**: Autocomplete for Tailwind classes
- **ES7+ React/Redux/React-Native snippets**: Code snippets for React
- **Volar** or **Vetur**: Vue.js support

## Installing Extensions

1. Click the Extensions icon in the left sidebar (or Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + X)
2. Search for the extension name
3. Click Install
4. Some require reload - click the reload button

## Configuring Prettier

Add to your settings.json:

```json
{
  "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode",
  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
  "prettier.singleQuote": true,
  "prettier.trailingComma": "es5"
}
```

## Common Mistakes

- **Installing too many extensions**: Slows down VS Code
- **Not configuring Prettier**: Default settings might not match your style
- **Forgetting to enable formatOnSave**: Missing the main benefit
- **Ignoring ESLint warnings**: They catch real bugs

## Try It Yourself

1. Install ESLint, Prettier, and GitLens
2. Create a test JavaScript file
3. Write some intentionally messy code
4. Save the file and watch Prettier format it

lessons.title: VS Code Configuration
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- User settings apply globally, workspace settings per project
- settings.json gives you full control
- Keyboard shortcuts save massive time
- Settings Sync keeps configs consistent across devices

---

## Settings Locations

### User Settings
- Applies to all projects
- Good for: themes, fonts, global shortcuts
- Location: `~/Library/Application Support/Code/User/settings.json` (Mac)

### Workspace Settings
- Applies only to current project
- Stored in `.vscode/settings.json`
- Good for: project-specific formatting, extensions

## Essential Settings

### Editor
```json
{
  "editor.fontSize": 14,
  "editor.fontFamily": "'JetBrains Mono', 'Fira Code', monospace",
  "editor.fontLigatures": true,
  "editor.minimap.enabled": false,
  "editor.wordWrap": "on"
}
```

### Files
```json
{
  "files.autoSave": "afterDelay",
  "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": true,
  "files.insertFinalNewline": true
}
```

### Explorer
```json
{
  "explorer.confirmDelete": false,
  "explorer.confirmDragAndDrop": false,
  "explorer.compactFolders": false
}
```

## Must-Know Keyboard Shortcuts

### Navigation
- `Cmd/Ctrl + P`: Quick file open
- `Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + P`: Command palette
- `Cmd/Ctrl + B`: Toggle sidebar
- `Cmd/Ctrl + J`: Toggle terminal

### Editing
- `Cmd/Ctrl + D`: Select next occurrence
- `Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + L`: Select all occurrences
- `Option/Alt + Up/Down`: Move line up/down
- `Cmd/Ctrl + /`: Toggle line comment

### Multi-cursor
- `Option/Alt + Click`: Place multiple cursors
- `Cmd/Ctrl + Option/Alt + Down`: Add cursor to next line

## Settings Sync

Enable in Settings → Settings Sync:
- Syncs settings, extensions, keyboard shortcuts
- Uses your GitHub or Microsoft account
- Essential when working on multiple machines

## Common Mistakes

- **Editing settings through UI only**: JSON is faster
- **Not using keyboard shortcuts**: Huge productivity loss
- **Over-customizing**: Start simple, add as needed
- **Forgetting workspace settings**: Keep project-specific configs

## Try It Yourself

1. Open settings.json (Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + P → "Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)")
2. Add the editor settings above
3. Try the keyboard shortcuts listed
4. Enable Settings Sync

lessons.title: Workspace Organization
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- Multi-root workspaces let you work on multiple projects
- Consistent folder structure saves mental overhead
- .vscode folder contains project-specific settings
- Good organization prevents "where is that file?" moments

---

## Project Folder Structure

Standard web project layout:

```
my-project/
├── .vscode/           # VS Code settings
├── src/               # Source code
│   ├── components/    # React components
│   ├── utils/         # Helper functions
│   └── styles/        # CSS/styling
├── public/            # Static assets
├── tests/             # Test files
├── docs/              # Documentation
├── .gitignore         # Git ignore rules
├── README.md          # Project info
└── package.json       # Dependencies
```

## The .vscode Folder

Create `.vscode/` in your project root for:

### settings.json
```json
{
  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
  "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode",
  "typescript.preferences.importModuleSpecifier": "relative"
}
```

### extensions.json
```json
{
  "recommendations": [
    "esbenp.prettier-vscode",
    "dbaeumer.vscode-eslint",
    "bradlc.vscode-tailwindcss"
  ]
}
```

### launch.json (for debugging)
```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch Program",
      "program": "${workspaceFolder}/src/index.js"
    }
  ]
}
```

## Multi-Root Workspaces

Work on multiple projects simultaneously:

1. File → Add Folder to Workspace
2. Save workspace as `my-workspace.code-workspace`
3. Opens multiple folders in one VS Code window
4. Each folder keeps its own settings

Useful for:
- Frontend + backend repos
- Monorepos
- Comparing codebases

## File Naming Conventions

Be consistent:
- `PascalCase` for React components (`UserProfile.jsx`)
- `camelCase` for utilities (`formatDate.js`)
- `kebab-case` for configs (`webpack-config.js`)
- `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE` for constants (`CONFIG.js`)

## Common Mistakes

- **Flat folder structure**: Everything in root becomes chaos
- **Inconsistent naming**: Mixing PascalCase and camelCase
- **Not using .vscode**: Missing project-specific optimizations
- **Too many folders**: Over-engineering simple projects

## Try It Yourself

1. Create a new folder for a practice project
2. Set up the folder structure above
3. Create a `.vscode/settings.json` with Prettier enabled
4. Add an `extensions.json` recommending ESLint

exercises.title: VS Code Extensions Quiz
exercises.description: Test your knowledge of essential VS Code extensions

questions.text: Which extension automatically formats your code on save?
questions.explanation: Prettier is a code formatter that automatically formats your code according to a consistent style. ESLint finds errors, GitLens adds Git features, and Path Intellisense helps with file paths.

options: Checks for code errors and style issues
questions.explanation: ESLint statically analyzes your JavaScript/TypeScript code to find problems. It catches syntax errors, unused variables, and style violations.

questions.text: Which extension helps you see who last modified a line of code?
questions.explanation: GitLens adds extensive Git integration to VS Code, including blame annotations that show who last modified each line and when.

exercises.title: VS Code Configuration Quiz
exercises.description: Test your knowledge of VS Code settings and shortcuts

questions.text: What's the keyboard shortcut to open the Command Palette?
questions.explanation: Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + P opens the Command Palette, which gives you access to all VS Code commands. Cmd/Ctrl + P opens the quick file navigator.
Workspace settings are stored in `.vscode/settings.json` within your project folder. User settings are global and stored in your VS Code configuration directory.

questions.text: What does the keyboard shortcut Cmd/Ctrl + D do?
questions.explanation: Cmd/Ctrl + D selects the next occurrence of the currently selected text, allowing you to edit multiple instances at once.

exercises.title: Configure VS Code Settings
exercises.description: Practice configuring VS Code by creating a settings.json file
exercises.instructions:
Create a VS Code settings.json configuration that:
1. Uses Prettier as the default formatter
2. Enables format on save
3. Sets font size to 15
4. Enables word wrap
5. Sets auto save to 'afterDelay'

Write the complete JSON object.
hints: The defaultFormatter should reference the Prettier extension ID: esbenp.prettier-vscode
exercises.validationPrompt:
Check if the user's JSON configuration includes:
1. editor.defaultFormatter set to 'esbenp.prettier-vscode'
2. editor.formatOnSave set to true
3. editor.fontSize set to 15
4. editor.wordWrap set to 'on'
5. files.autoSave set to 'afterDelay'

The JSON should be valid and contain all five settings.
